<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_BSP_Lock_Impl:
```c
void OS_BSP_Lock_Impl(void)
{
    int status;

    status = pthread_mutex_lock(&OS_BSP_GenericLinuxGlobal.AccessMutex);
    if (status < 0)
    {
        BSP_DEBUG("pthread_mutex_lock: %s\n", strerror(status));
    }
    else
    {
        /*
         * Temporarily Disable/Defer thread cancellation.
         * Note that OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl() calls write() which is a cancellation point.
         * So if this calling task is canceled, it risks leaving the BSP locked.
         */
        pthread_setcancelstate(PTHREAD_CANCEL_DISABLE, &OS_BSP_GenericLinuxGlobal.AccessCancelState);
    }
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No compiler language extensions are used in the provided code. I inspected the fragment for common compiler-specific extensions that are explicitly documented as extensions (for example: GCC/Clang __attribute__ or __attribute__((...)), __asm__/asm statements, inline assembly, nested functions, statement-expressions ({ ...; }) with GNU ({ }), typeof/__typeof__, __extension__, labels as values (&&label), builtins that are extensions, vector extensions, or other compiler-specific keywords). None of these appear. The code only calls standard POSIX/C library functions (pthread_mutex_lock, pthread_setcancelstate, strerror, write is mentioned in the comment) and uses standard C syntax (variable declaration, function definition, if/else, comments). POSIX APIs are platform/library interfaces, not compiler language extensions, so they do not trigger Rule 1.2. Therefore there are no code fragments requiring investigation for use of language extensions.
